faq.questionGeneral1: How can I book an appointment?
faq.answerGeneral1: You can easily book piercing appointments using our contact form or by phone. If you'd like a tattoo, we ask you to come to the studio in person to discuss your idea and make a deposit.
faq.answerGeneral2: We offer walk-in days for tattoos. However, you should always make an appointment for a tattoo. For piercings, walk-ins are welcome! although there may be a short waiting time
faq.questionGeneral3: How old do I have to be for a tattoo or piercing?
faq.answerGeneral3: You generally have to be at least 18 years old to get a tattoo. In exceptional cases, we also accept tattoos from the age of 16, provided a parent or legal guardian is present at the consultation. To schedule an appointment, we require: a written consent form, ID cards for both parents, and, if the parents have different last names, a birth certificate. For piercings, the following applies: From the age of 14, with personal supervision by a parent and presentation of ID cards. From the age of 16, a written consent form with a copy of the parents' ID cards is sufficient. We also offer ear piercing for children â€“ from the age of 6. It is particularly important to us that the child clearly expresses their own wishes and feels safe â€“ not just at the request of the parents.
faq.questionGeneral4: What do I need to bring to my appointment?
faq.answerGeneral4: Please bring a valid ID to your piercing appointment â€“ â€‹â€‹we can't treat you without it. Eat something beforehand to stabilize your circulation. Feel free to bring a small snack and a drink (no zero-calorie drinks) to keep your blood sugar levels up for your tattoo appointment. A book, podcast, or music helps many people relax or distract themselves from the pain â€“ bring whatever feels good!
faq.answerGeneral5: Yes, you can get vouchers at the counter, or if you live further away, we'll be happy to send you one.
faq.questionTattoo1: How does the tattooing process work?
faq.answerTattoo1: Typically, you bring your idea or desired motif to the studio. We'll discuss the placement, size, and approximate price with you. After scheduling an appointment, you'll contact the tattoo artist directly. You'll usually receive your design shortly before your appointmentâ€”usually one day in advance. Minor adjustments can, of course, be made up until the tattooing appointment. A deposit is required to reserve an appointment. This will be retained for appointments not canceled in a timely manner (at least three business days in advance). In acute emergencies, we will of course be accommodating, but please inform us as early as possible in any case.
faq.questionTattoo2: How do I prepare for my tattoo appointment?
faq.answerTattoo2: Please arrive well-rested, healthy, and refreshed for your appointment. Eat well on the day of your appointment, ideally a balanced breakfast, and a small meal shortly beforehand â€“ this will help your circulation. Feel free to bring something to drink and, for longer sessions, a small snack. Avoid alcohol or other substances the day before â€“ painkillers like aspirin or ibuprofen are also taboo, as they have a blood-thinning effect. The fitter and more relaxed you are, the more pleasant your tattoo experience will be.
faq.questionTattoo3: How much does a tattoo cost?
faq.answerTattoo3: Of course, this depends entirely on the design, size, and body part. An hour's session costs around â‚¬150, and a day session costs around â‚¬850. Please discuss this thoroughly with the tattoo artist to avoid leaving the session feeling frustrated.
faq.questionTattoo4: Do I have to be sober for my tattoo appointment?
faq.answerTattoo4: Yes. Please. Absolutely. Even if you're on a tear â€“ when getting a tattoo, your body needs to be sober and your head clear. Alcohol or other substances before your appointment? Not a good idea. Not only because they thin the blood and make it harder for the skin to work â€“ the tattoo artist also appreciates clear communication and no beer breath during the final puncture. If we notice this, we'll unfortunately have to send you home with a red card.
faq.questionTattoo5: What if I'm sick or on my period?
faq.answerTattoo5: If you notice that you're getting sick, please let us know in advance â€“ ideally at least three working days before your appointment. If it comes on suddenly and you realize that morning that you're not feeling well, please still contact us immediately. Even if you've waited a long time for your appointment â€“ â€‹â€‹your health and that of our artists are our top priority. We thank you for your consideration and sense of responsibility. If you're on your period: Of course, you can still attend your appointment. However, please be aware that your body may be more sensitive during this time â€“ both physically and emotionally. If you're not feeling well, talk to us. We can take more breaks; you're welcome to bring a painkiller (please not blood-thinning aspirin), or take care of yourself with tea, snacks, or a hot water bottle.
faq.answerTattoo6: We generally don't use anesthetics. There are several reasons for this: Firstly, we don't know how your body will react to the active ingredients â€“ this can be problematic, especially with sensitive or allergic skin. Secondly, we believe that pain is part of the process â€“ and can certainly have a transformative effect. Often the idea is worse than reality. Your body knows what to do: After just a short time, it releases adrenaline, endorphins, and serotonin â€“ a natural cocktail that relieves pain and can even put you into a pleasant flow state. Many even report a feeling of relief, strength, or inner clarity afterwards. So: breathe deeply, you can do it. We will accompany you mindfully â€“ with experience, calm, and a great deal of sensitivity.
faq.questionTattoo7: What happens if I'm dissatisfied with my tattoo?
faq.answerTattoo7: Of course, we hope you'll wear your new tattoo with pride and joy â€“ that's why we place great value on clear communication, a coherent motif, and calm, trusting consultations right from the start. Everything is coordinated with you before the needle even touches skin. But: Skin isn't paper, and a tattoo isn't a print job. It lives, works, and heals â€“ and small variations are part of the craft. That's exactly what makes a tattoo unique. Should something get lost during healing or small areas develop unevenly, we'll of course offer you a free touch-up â€“ that's included in the price. And if your perspective on your tattoo changes over the course of your life? That's okay too. There are options like cover-ups or laser lightening, which we'll give you honest advice about. In the end, perfection lies not in flawlessness, but in meaning. And your tattoo tells a story â€“ yours.

faq.answerTattooCare2: Your fresh tattoo is like a small wound â€“ and should be treated the same way. To ensure it heals beautifully and the colors shine, you should definitely avoid a few things in the first few weeks: âŒ No swimming (no lake, pool, whirlpool, or ocean â€“ water harbors germs that can cause infections. Avoid water baths for at least 2â€“4 weeks). âŒ No saunas or tanning beds (heat, steam, and UV radiation are toxic to your fresh tattoo. Also avoid direct sunlight! Always cover it up or protect it with a high SPF (after healing)). âŒ No scratching or peeling (yes, it itches. Yes, it flakes. But please: don't pick, don't scratch, don't rub. This will tear out the ink and skin â€“ and the tattoo will become spotty). âŒ No sports (at the beginning) (sweat, friction, and mechanical Stress isn't good for the skin. Pause intense exercise for 2â€“7 days, depending on the area of â€‹â€‹the body. âŒ Avoid tight clothing (anything that chafes or sticks can irritate the tattoo. It's best to wear airy, clean clothing). âœ… Instead: Keep it clean, well-groomed, protectedâ€”and keep an eye on it. If you have any questions or concerns, we're here to help.
faq.questionTattooCare3: How long does it take to heal?
faq.answerTattooCare3: A tattoo heals in several phases â€“ and how quickly your skin heals depends on many factors: your care, your skin type, the area inked, and also your immune system. A rough timeline: First phase (1â€“3 days): The skin is freshly injured, possibly slightly red and sensitive. Wound discharge, slight swelling, or tightness are completely normal. Second phase (3â€“14 days): Scabs form, and the skin may itch or peel â€“ like after a sunburn. Please do not scratch or peel, even if it's difficult! Third phase (from 2 weeks): The upper layer of skin looks 'healed' again, but your tattoo continues to heal in the deeper layers. A tattoo is usually completely healed after about 4 to 6 weeks. With sensitive skin or larger motifs, it can sometimes take up to 8 weeks. Important: Even if it already looks good, your tattoo is only truly 'finished' when it has fully healed. Follow our care instructions and protect it from sun and stress.
faq.questionTattooCare4: What is normal during the healing phase and what isn't?
faq.answerTattooCare4: Let's be honest: Your tattoo is just a small wound â€“ and, like any wound, needs to be treated well. Please avoid the following in the first few days: Bathing, swimming, saunas, or tanning beds â€“ water, heat, and UV radiation are absolute no-gos for your fresh tattoo. Exercise and heavy sweating â€“ give yourself and your skin a few days of rest. Crawling, picking, or rubbing â€“ even if it itches: keep your hands off! The scab should fall off on its own. Perfumed creams or disinfectants â€“ it's better to only use the care products we recommend. This is normal during the healing process: Slight burning, tightness, or itching. Slight redness or scabbing. Colored wound discharge (don't be alarmed â€“ this is often a mixture of ink and wound fluid). The skin peels slightly, like after a sunburn. This is not normal: Severe redness, swelling, or throbbing pain for several days. Purulent discharge or an unpleasant odor. Fever or a general feeling of illness. If you are unsure, it is better to contact us too often than too little. We are here for you and will accompany you through the healing process even after the tattoo.
faq.questionTattooCare5: What do I do if the tattoo becomes infected?
faq.answerTattooCare5: Please come by and let us take a look. Saby is a nurse and is trained to assess wounds honestly.
